member.name: T:Win32.IO.FileAccess
member.summary: Defines the specific access rights to files and directories. See for more information.

member.name: F:Win32.IO.FileAccess.FILE_READ_DATA
member.summary: For a file object, the right to read the corresponding file data. For a directory object, the right to read the corresponding directory data.

member.name: F:Win32.IO.FileAccess.FILE_LIST_DIRECTORY
member.summary: For a directory, the right to list the contents of the directory.

member.name: F:Win32.IO.FileAccess.FILE_WRITE_DATA
member.summary: For a file object, the right to write data to the file.

member.name: F:Win32.IO.FileAccess.FILE_ADD_FILE
member.summary: For a directory, the right to create a file in the directory.

member.name: F:Win32.IO.FileAccess.FILE_APPEND_DATA
member.summary: For a file object, the right to append data to the file.

member.name: F:Win32.IO.FileAccess.FILE_ADD_SUBDIRECTORY
member.summary: For a directory, the right to create a subdirectory.

member.name: F:Win32.IO.FileAccess.FILE_CREATE_PIPE_INSTANCE
member.summary: For a named pipe, the right to create a pipe.

member.name: F:Win32.IO.FileAccess.FILE_READ_EA
member.summary: The right to read extended file attributes.

member.name: F:Win32.IO.FileAccess.FILE_WRITE_EA
member.summary: The right to write extended file attributes.

member.name: F:Win32.IO.FileAccess.FILE_EXECUTE
member.summary: For a native code file, the right to execute the file. This access right given to scripts may cause the script to be executable, depending on the script interpreter.

member.name: F:Win32.IO.FileAccess.FILE_TRAVERSE
member.summary: For a directory, the right to traverse the directory.

member.name: F:Win32.IO.FileAccess.FILE_DELETE_CHILD
member.summary: For a directory, the right to delete a directory and all the files it contains, including read-only files.

member.name: F:Win32.IO.FileAccess.FILE_READ_ATTRIBUTES
member.summary: The right to read file attributes.

member.name: F:Win32.IO.FileAccess.FILE_WRITE_ATTRIBUTES
member.summary: The right to write file attributes.

member.name: F:Win32.IO.FileAccess.FILE_ALL_ACCESS
member.summary: All possible access rights for a file.

member.name: T:Win32.IO.FilePointerMoveMethod
member.summary: Defines the starting points for the file pointer move operations.

member.name: F:Win32.IO.FilePointerMoveMethod.FILE_BEGIN
member.summary: The starting point is zero or the beginning of the file.

member.name: F:Win32.IO.FilePointerMoveMethod.FILE_CURRENT
member.summary: The starting point is the current value of the file pointer.

member.name: F:Win32.IO.FilePointerMoveMethod.FILE_END
member.summary: The starting point is the current end-of-file position.

member.name: T:Win32.IO.FILE_ACTION
member.summary: Defined the type of change that can occur in directories.

member.name: F:Win32.IO.FILE_ACTION.ADDED
member.summary: A file was added to the directory.

member.name: F:Win32.IO.FILE_ACTION.REMOVED
member.summary: A file was removed from the directory.

member.name: F:Win32.IO.FILE_ACTION.MODIFIED
member.summary: A file was modified. This can be a change in the time stamp or attributes.

member.name: F:Win32.IO.FILE_ACTION.RENAMED_OLD_NAME
member.summary: The file was renamed, since an action notification report carries only one file name, two reports transport the information. This is the old name.

member.name: F:Win32.IO.FILE_ACTION.RENAMED_NEW_NAME
member.summary: The file was renamed, since an action notification report carries only one file name, two reports transport the information. This is the new name.

member.name: T:Win32.IO.FILE_GENERIC
member.summary: Defines how the generic access right for files and directories are made up, using specific and standard access rights. Use either these values or GENERIC.* or ACCESS_MASK.GENERIC_*. See for more information.

member.name: F:Win32.IO.FILE_GENERIC.FILE_GENERIC_READ
member.summary: Collects the specific and standard access rights, that are set for GENERIC_READ.

member.name: F:Win32.IO.FILE_GENERIC.FILE_GENERIC_WRITE
member.summary: Collects the specific and standard access rights, that are set for GENERIC_WRITE.

member.name: F:Win32.IO.FILE_GENERIC.FILE_GENERIC_EXECUTE
member.summary: Collects the specific and standard access rights, that are set for GENERIC_EXECUTE.

member.name: T:Win32.IO.FILE_NOTIFY_CHANGE
member.summary: Defines filters for directory change notification.

member.name: F:Win32.IO.FILE_NOTIFY_CHANGE.FILE_NAME
member.summary: Return on any file name change, or on creating or deleting of a file.

member.name: F:Win32.IO.FILE_NOTIFY_CHANGE.DIR_NAME
member.summary: Return on any directory name change, or on creating or deleting of a directory.

member.name: F:Win32.IO.FILE_NOTIFY_CHANGE.ATTRIBUTES
member.summary: Return on any attribute change.

member.name: F:Win32.IO.FILE_NOTIFY_CHANGE.SIZE
member.summary: Return on any size change.

member.name: F:Win32.IO.FILE_NOTIFY_CHANGE.LAST_WRITE
member.summary: Return on any change on the last write time of a file.

member.name: F:Win32.IO.FILE_NOTIFY_CHANGE.LAST_ACCESS
member.summary: Return on any change on the last access time of a file.

member.name: F:Win32.IO.FILE_NOTIFY_CHANGE.CREATION
member.summary: Return on any change on the creation time of a file.

member.name: F:Win32.IO.FILE_NOTIFY_CHANGE.SECURITY
member.summary: Return on any change on the security-descriptor in the watch directory.

member.name: T:Win32.IO.FileOperations
member.summary: Class for file operations.

member.name: F:Win32.IO.FileOperations.INVALID_HANDLE_VALUE
member.summary: Is returns by some file operations, denoting an error has occurred.

member.name: F:Win32.IO.FileOperations.INVALID_SET_FILE_POINTER
member.summary: If returns this value and returns NO_ERROR (0), it is the position of the file pointer, and not an error.

member.name: F:Win32.IO.FileOperations.INVALID_FILE_SIZE
member.summary: If returns this value and returns NO_ERROR (0), it is the position of the file pointer, and not an error.

member.name: M:Win32.IO.FileOperations.CreateFile(System.String,Win32.IO.FileAccess,Win32.IO.FILE_SHARE,System.IntPtr,Win32.IO.FileMode,Win32.IO.FILE_ATTRIBUTE,System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Creates or opens a file and I/O device.
member.param: The name of the file or device to be created or opened.
The requested access to the file or device.
The requested sharing mode of the file or device.
A pointer to a structure. Can be null (IntPtr.Zero).
An action to take on a file or device that exists or does not exist.
The file or device attributes and flags.
A valid handle to a template file with the access right. Can be null (IntPtr.Zero).
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is an open handle to the specified file or device. If the function fails, the return value is . To get extended error information, call .

member.name: M:Win32.IO.FileOperations.GetFileSize(System.IntPtr,System.IntPtr)
member.summary: Retrieves the size of the specified file, in bytes.
member.param: A handle to the file.
A pointer to a uint variable to receive the high order 32 bits of the file size. If the parameter is null (IntPtr.Zero) no high order bits are returned.
member.returns: If the function succeeds, the return value is the low-order 32 bit of the file size; otherwise is returned.

member.name: T:Win32.IO.FileFlagsAndAttributes
member.summary: Used by CreateFile as combined parameter for FILE_FLAG_*, FILE_ATTRIBUTE_* and SECURITY_*.

member.name: F:Win32.IO.FileFlagsAndAttributes.READONLY
member.summary: A file that is read-only. Applications can read the file, but cannot write to it or delete it.

member.name: F:Win32.IO.FileFlagsAndAttributes.HIDDEN
member.summary: Marks a file or directory as hidden.

member.name: F:Win32.IO.FileFlagsAndAttributes.SYSTEM
member.summary: A file or directory of the operating system.

member.name: F:Win32.IO.FileFlagsAndAttributes.ARCHIVE
member.summary: Used to mark file and directories for backup.

member.name: F:Win32.IO.FileFlagsAndAttributes.NORMAL
member.summary: A file that does not have other attributes set. This attribute is valid only when used alone.

member.name: F:Win32.IO.FileFlagsAndAttributes.TEMPORARY
member.summary: Marks a file as temporary storage. The system delays writing data to mass storage, if possible, since the file is most likely to be delete after use.

member.name: F:Win32.IO.FileFlagsAndAttributes.OFFLINE
member.summary: Marks a file that is moved to an offline storage and not immediately available.

member.name: F:Win32.IO.FileFlagsAndAttributes.ENCRYPTED
member.summary: Marks a file or directory that is encrypted.

member.name: F:Win32.IO.FileFlagsAndAttributes.OPEN_REQUIRING_OPLOCK
member.summary: The file is being opened and an opportunistic lock (oplock) on the file is being requested as a single atomic operation. The file system checks for oplocks before it performs the create operation, and will fail the create with a last error code of ERROR_CANNOT_BREAK_OPLOCK if the result would be to break an existing oplock.

member.name: F:Win32.IO.FileFlagsAndAttributes.OPEN_NO_RECALL
member.summary: Used with remote storage systems. File data is requested, but it should stay in remote storage.

member.name: F:Win32.IO.FileFlagsAndAttributes.OPEN_REPARSE_POINT
member.summary: Disables reparse point processing and opens the reparse point itself, if one.

member.name: F:Win32.IO.FileFlagsAndAttributes.SESSION_AWARE
member.summary: The file or device is being opened with session awareness.
member.remarks: This flag is supported only on server editions of Windows. Note: This flag is not supported until Windows Server 2012.

member.name: F:Win32.IO.FileFlagsAndAttributes.POSIX_SEMANTICS
member.summary: Use POSIX rules for file access.

member.name: F:Win32.IO.FileFlagsAndAttributes.BACKUP_SEMANTICS
member.summary: The file or directory is being opened or created for a backup or restore operation.

member.name: F:Win32.IO.FileFlagsAndAttributes.DELETE_ON_CLOSE
member.summary: The file is to be deleted immediately after it is closed.

member.name: F:Win32.IO.FileFlagsAndAttributes.SEQUENTIAL_SCAN
member.summary: Access is intended to be sequential from beginning to end. Hints the system for caching optimizations.

member.name: F:Win32.IO.FileFlagsAndAttributes.RANDOM_ACCESS
member.summary: Access is intended to be random. Hints the system for caching optimizations.

member.name: F:Win32.IO.FileFlagsAndAttributes.NO_BUFFERING
member.summary: The file or device is being opened with no system caching for data reads and writes.

member.name: F:Win32.IO.FileFlagsAndAttributes.OVERLAPPED
member.summary: The file or device is being opened or created for asynchronous I/O.

member.name: F:Win32.IO.FileFlagsAndAttributes.WRITE_THROUGH
member.summary: Write operations will not go through any intermediate cache, they will go directly to mass storage.

member.name: F:Win32.IO.FileFlagsAndAttributes.ANONYMOUS
member.summary: Impersonates a client at the Anonymous impersonation level.

member.name: F:Win32.IO.FileFlagsAndAttributes.IDENTIFICATION
member.summary: Impersonates a client at the Identification impersonation level.

member.name: F:Win32.IO.FileFlagsAndAttributes.IMPERSONATION
member.summary: Impersonate a client at the impersonation level. This is the default behavior if no other flags are specified along with the SECURITY_SQOS_PRESENT flag.

member.name: F:Win32.IO.FileFlagsAndAttributes.DELEGATION
member.summary: Impersonates a client at the Delegation impersonation level.

member.name: F:Win32.IO.FileFlagsAndAttributes.CONTEXT_TRACKING
member.summary: The security tracking mode is dynamic. If this flag is not specified, the security tracking mode is static.

summary.para: Only the enabled aspects of the client's security context are available to the server. If you do not specify this flag, all aspects of the client's security context are available.
This allows the client to limit the groups and privileges that a server can use while impersonating the client.

member.name: F:Win32.IO.FileFlagsAndAttributes.SQOS_PRESENT
member.summary: Security quality of service flags.

member.name: F:Win32.IO.FileFlagsAndAttributes.VALID_SQOS_FLAGS
member.summary: Bitmask for valid security quality of service flags.

The number of structures pointed to by array.
The size, in bytes, of the structure.
member.returns: If successful, the function returns S_OK (IntPtr.Zero). Otherwise it returns an error value.

member.name: M:Win32.IO.RawInput.RawInput.GetRawInputBuffer(System.IntPtr,System.UInt32@,System.UInt32)
member.summary: Performs a buffered read of the raw input data.

remarks.para: Using , the raw input data is buffered in the array of structures. For an unbuffered read, listen to WM_INPUT and use the message details to read the raw input data.
The methode allows an application to traverse an array of structures.
Note: To get the correct size of the raw input buffer, do not use , use *8 instead.

member.param: A pointer to a buffer of structures that contain the raw input data. If null (IntPtr.Zero), the minimum required buffer, in bytes, is returned in .
The size, in bytes, of a structure.
The size, in bytes, of the structure.

returns.para: If is null and the function is successful, the return value is zero (0). If is not null and the function is successful, the return value is the number of structures written to .
If an error occurs, the return value is (-1). Call for the error code.

member.name: M:Win32.IO.RawInput.RawInput.GetRawInputData(System.IntPtr,Win32.IO.RawInput.RID,System.IntPtr,System.UInt32@,System.UInt32)
member.summary: Retrieves the raw input from the specified device.
member.remarks: gets the raw input one structure at a time. In contrast, gets an array of structures.
member.param: A handle to the structure. This comes from the lParam in WM_INPUT.
The command flag. See for more information.
A pointer to the data that comes from the structure. This depends on the value of . If pData is null (IntPtr.Zero), the required size of the buffer is returned in .
The size, in bytes, of the data in .
The size, in bytes, of the structure.

returns.para: If is null (IntPtr.Zero) and the function is successful, the return value is zero (0). If is not null (IntPtr.Zero) and the function is successful, the return value is the number of bytes copied into pData.
If there is an error, the return value is (-1).

member.name: M:Win32.IO.RawInput.RawInput.GetRawInputDeviceInfo(System.IntPtr,Win32.IO.RawInput.RIDI,System.IntPtr,System.UInt32@)
member.summary: Retrieves information about the raw input device. (Use only in environments that have == 2.)
member.param: A handle to the raw input device. This comes from the lParam of the WM_INPUT message, from the hDevice member of , or from . It can also be null (IntPtr.Zero) if an application inserts input data, for example, by using SendInput.
Specifies what data will be returned in . See for more information.
A pointer to a buffer that contains the information specified by . If is , set the cbSize member of to sizeof(RID_DEVICE_INFO) before calling .
The size, in bytes or characters (if is ), of the data in .

returns.para: If successful, this function returns a non-negative number indicating the number of bytes or characters (if is ) copied to .

If is not large enough for the data, the function returns (-1). If is null (IntPtr.Zero), the function returns a value of zero (0). In both of these cases, is set to the minimum size required for the buffer.
Call to identify any other errors.

member.name: M:Win32.IO.RawInput.RawInput.GetRawInputDeviceList(Win32.IO.RawInput.RAWINPUTDEVICELIST[],System.UInt32@,System.UInt32)
member.summary: Enumerates the raw input devices attached to the system.

remarks.para: The devices returned from this function are the mouse, the keyboard, and other Human Interface Device (HID) devices.
To get more detailed information about the attached devices, call using the hDevice from .

member.param: An array of structures for the devices attached to the system. If null, the number of devices are returned in .

If is null, the function populates this variable with the number of devices attached to the system; otherwise, this variable specifies the number of structures that can be contained in the buffer to which points. If this value is less than the number of devices attached to the system, the function returns the actual number of devices in this variable and fails with .
The size of a structure, in bytes.

returns.para: If the function is successful, the return value is the number of devices stored in the buffer pointed to by .
On any other error, the function returns (-1) and returns the error indication.

member.name: M:Win32.IO.RawInput.RawInput.GetRegisteredRawInputDevices(Win32.IO.RawInput.RAWINPUTDEVICE[],System.UInt32@,System.UInt32)
member.summary: Retrieves the information about the raw input devices for the current application.
member.remarks: To receive raw input from a device, an application must register it by using .
member.param: An array of structures for the application.
The number of structures in .
The size, in bytes, of a structure.

returns.para: If successful, the function returns a non-negative number that is the number of structures written to the buffer.

If the buffer is too small or null (IntPtr.Zero), the function sets the last error as , returns (-1), and sets to the required number of devices. If the function fails for any other reason, it returns (-1). For more details, call .

member.name: M:Win32.IO.RawInput.RawInput.RegisterRawInputDevices(Win32.IO.RawInput.RAWINPUTDEVICE[],System.UInt32,System.UInt32)
member.summary: Registers the devices that supply the raw input data.

remarks.para: To receive WM_INPUT messages, an application must first register the raw input devices using . By default, an application does not receive raw input.

To receive WM_INPUT_DEVICE_CHANGE messages, an application must specify the flag for each device class that is specified by the usUsagePage and usUsage fields of the structure. By default, an application does not receive WM_INPUT_DEVICE_CHANGE notifications for raw input device arrival and removal.
If a structure has the flag set and the hwndTarget parameter is not set to null (IntPtr.Zero), then parameter validation will fail.

member.param: An array of structures that represent the devices that supply the raw input.
The number of structures pointed to by .
The size, in bytes, of a structure.
member.returns: true if the function succeeds; otherwise, false. If the function fails, call for more information.

remarks.para: If RIDEV_NOLEGACY is set for a mouse or a keyboard, the system does not generate any legacy message for that device for the application. For example, if the mouse TLC is set with RIDEV_NOLEGACY, WM_LBUTTONDOWN and related legacy mouse messages are not generated. Likewise, if the keyboard TLC is set with RIDEV_NOLEGACY, WM_KEYDOWN and related legacy keyboard messages are not generated.

member.summary: If set, this prevents any devices specified by or from generating legacy messages. This is only for the mouse and keyboard. See Remarks.

member.name: F:Win32.IO.RawInput.RIDEV.INPUTSINK
member.summary: If set, this enables the caller to receive the input even when the caller is not in the foreground. Note that must be specified.

member.name: F:Win32.IO.RawInput.RIDEV.CAPTUREMOUSE
member.summary: If set, the mouse button click does not activate the other window.

member.name: F:Win32.IO.RawInput.RIDEV.NOHOTKEYS
member.summary: If set, the application-defined keyboard device hotkeys are not handled. However, the system hotkeys; for example, [ALT]+[TAB] and [CTRL]+[ALT]+[DEL], are still handled. By default, all keyboard hotkeys are handled. RIDEV_NOHOTKEYS can be specified even if RIDEV_NOLEGACY is not specified and is null (IntPtr.Zero).

member.name: F:Win32.IO.RawInput.RIDEV.APPKEYS
member.summary: If set, the application command keys are handled. RIDEV_APPKEYS can be specified only if RIDEV_NOLEGACY is specified for a keyboard device.

member.name: F:Win32.IO.RawInput.RIDEV.EXINPUTSINK
member.summary: If set, this enables the caller to receive input in the background only if the foreground application does not process it. In other words, if the foreground application is not registered for raw input, then the background application that is registered will receive the input.
member.remarks: Windows XP: This flag is not supported until Windows Vista

member.name: F:Win32.IO.RawInput.RIDEV.DEVNOTIFY
member.summary: If set, this enables the caller to receive WM_INPUT_DEVICE_CHANGE notifications for device arrival and device removal. This works only when is also set (and of course must be specified).
member.remarks: Windows XP: This flag is not supported until Windows Vista

member.name: F:Win32.IO.RawInput.RIDEV.EXMODEMASK
member.summary: Usage: mode&RIDEV.EXMODEMASK.

member.name: T:Win32.MultiMedia.WinMM
member.summary: Windows Multimedia binding for .NET, implementing Windows-specific multimedia functionality.

member.name: F:Win32.MultiMedia.WinMM.SND_SYNC
member.summary: Synchronous playback of a sound event. PlaySound returns after the sound event completes.

member.name: F:Win32.MultiMedia.WinMM.SND_ASYNC
member.summary: The sound is played asynchronously and PlaySound returns immediately after beginning the sound. To terminate an asynchronously played waveform sound, call PlaySound with sound set to NULL.

member.name: F:Win32.MultiMedia.WinMM.SND_NODEFAULT
member.summary: No default sound event is used. If the sound cannot be found, PlaySound returns silently without playing the default sound.

member.name: F:Win32.MultiMedia.WinMM.SND_MEMORY
member.summary: A sound event's file is loaded in RAM. The parameter specified by sound must point to an image of a sound in memory.

member.name: F:Win32.MultiMedia.WinMM.SND_LOOP
member.summary: The sound plays repeatedly until PlaySound is called again with the sound parameter set to NULL. You must also specify the flag to indicate an asynchronous sound event.

summary.para: The specified sound event will yield to another sound event that is already playing. If a sound cannot be played because the resource needed to generate that sound is busy playing another sound, the function immediately returns FALSE without playing the requested sound.
If this flag is not specified, PlaySound attempts to stop the currently playing sound so that the device can be used to play the new sound.

member.name: F:Win32.MultiMedia.WinMM.SND_NOWAIT
member.summary: If the driver is busy, return immediately without playing the sound.

member.name: F:Win32.MultiMedia.WinMM.SND_ALIAS
member.summary: The sound parameter is a system-event alias in the registry or the WIN.INI file. Do not use with either or .

member.name: F:Win32.MultiMedia.WinMM.SND_ALIAS_ID
member.summary: The sound parameter is a predefined sound identifier.

member.name: F:Win32.MultiMedia.WinMM.SND_FILENAME
member.summary: The sound parameter is a filename.

member.name: F:Win32.MultiMedia.WinMM.SND_RESOURCE
member.summary: The sound parameter is a resource identifier; mod must identify the instance that contains the resource.

summary.para: Sounds are to be stopped for the calling task. If sound is not NULL, all instances of the specified sound are stopped. If sound is NULL, all sounds that are playing on behalf of the calling task are stopped.
You must also specify the instance handle to stop events.

member.name: F:Win32.MultiMedia.WinMM.SND_APPLICATION
member.summary: The sound is played using an application-specific association.

member.name: T:Win32.MultiMedia.WinMM.JOYINFOEX
member.summary: The JOYINFOEX structure contains extended information about the joystick position, point-of-view position, and button state.

remarks.para: The value of the dwSize member is also used to identify the version number for the structure when it's passed to the function.
Most devices with a point-of-view control have only five positions. When the JOY_RETURNPOV flag is set, these positions are reported by using the following constants:

- Point-of-view hat is pressed backward. The value 18,000 represents an orientation of 180.00 degrees (to the rear). - Point-of-view hat is in the neutral position. The value -1 means the point-of-view hat has no angle to report. - Point-of-view hat is pressed forward. The value 0 represents an orientation of 0.00 degrees (straight ahead). - Point-of-view hat is being pressed to the left. The value 27,000 represents an orientation of 270.00 degrees (90.00 degrees to the left). - Point-of-view hat is pressed to the right. The value 9,000 represents an orientation of 90.00 degrees (to the right).

The default joystick driver currently supports these five discrete directions. If an application can accept only the defined point-of-view values, it must use the JOY_RETURNPOV flag. If an application can accept other degree readings, it should use the JOY_RETURNPOVCTS flag to obtain continuous data if it is available. The JOY_RETURNPOVCTS flag also supports the JOY_POV constants used with the JOY_RETURNPOV flag.

member.name: F:Win32.MultiMedia.WinMM.JOYINFOEX.dwSize
member.summary: Size, in bytes, of this structure.

member.name: F:Win32.MultiMedia.WinMM.JOYINFOEX.dwFlags
member.summary: Flags indicating the valid information returned in this structure. Members that do not contain valid information are set to zero.

remarks.para: - Equivalent to setting all of the JOY_RETURN bits except JOY_RETURNRAWDATA. - The dwButtons member contains valid information about the state of each joystick button. - Centers the joystick neutral position to the middle value of each axis of movement. - The dwPOV member contains valid information about the point-of-view control, expressed in discrete units. - The dwPOV member contains valid information about the point-of-view control expressed in continuous, one-hundredth degree units. - The dwRpos member contains valid rudder pedal data. This information represents another (fourth) axis. - Data stored in this structure is uncalibrated joystick readings. - The dwUpos member contains valid data for a fifth axis of the joystick, if such an axis is available, or returns zero otherwise. - The dwVpos member contains valid data for a sixth axis of the joystick, if such an axis is available, or returns zero otherwise. - The dwXpos member contains valid data for the x-coordinate of the joystick. - The dwYpos member contains valid data for the y-coordinate of the joystick. - The dwZpos member contains valid data for the z-coordinate of the joystick. - Expands the range for the neutral position of the joystick and calls this range the dead zone. The joystick driver returns a constant value for all positions in the dead zone.
The following flags provide data to calibrate a joystick and are intended for custom calibration applications.

- Read the x-, y-, and z-coordinates and store the raw values in dwXpos, dwYpos, and dwZpos. - Read the rudder information and the x-, y-, and z-coordinates and store the raw values in dwXpos, dwYpos, dwZpos, and dwRpos. - Read the rudder information and the x-, y-, z-, and u-coordinates and store the raw values in dwXpos, dwYpos, dwZpos, dwRpos, and dwUpos. - Read the raw v-axis data if a joystick mini driver is present that will provide the data. Returns zero otherwise. - Read the joystick port even if the driver does not detect a device. - Read the rudder information if a joystick mini-driver is present that will provide the data and store the raw value in dwRpos. Return zero otherwise. - Read the x-coordinate and store the raw (uncalibrated) value in dwXpos. - Reads the x- and y-coordinates and place the raw values in dwXpos and dwYpos. - Reads the y-coordinate and store the raw value in dwYpos. - Read the z-coordinate and store the raw value in dwZpos. - Read the u-coordinate if a joystick mini-driver is present that will provide the data and store the raw value in dwUpos. Return zero otherwise. - Read the v-coordinate if a joystick mini-driver is present that will provide the data and store the raw value in dwVpos. Return zero otherwise.

member.name: M:Win32.MultiMedia.WinMM.PlaySound(System.String,System.IntPtr,System.UInt32)
member.summary: The PlaySound function plays a sound specified by the given filename, resource, or system event. (A system event may be associated with a sound in the registry or in the WIN.INI file.)

param.name: sound
param.para: A string that specifies the sound to play. If this parameter is NULL, any currently playing waveform sound is stopped. To stop a non-waveform sound, specify in the soundFlags parameter.

Three flags in soundFlags (, , and ) determine whether the name is interpreted as an alias for a system event, a filename, or a resource identifier. If none of these flags are specified, PlaySound searches the registry or the WIN.INI file for an association with the specified sound name. If an association is found, the sound event is played. If no association is found in the registry, the name is interpreted as a filename.

member.param: Handle to the executable file that contains the resource to be loaded. This parameter must be NULL unless is specified in soundFlags.

param.name: soundFlags
param.para: Flags for playing the sound. The following values are defined:

item.description: The sound is played using an application-specific association.
The sound parameter is a system-event alias in the registry or the WIN.INI file. Do not use with either or .
The sound parameter is a predefined sound identifier.
The sound is played asynchronously and PlaySound returns immediately after beginning the sound. To terminate an asynchronously played waveform sound, call PlaySound with sound set to NULL.
The sound parameter is a filename.
The sound plays repeatedly until PlaySound is called again with the sound parameter set to NULL. You must also specify the flag to indicate an asynchronous sound event.
A sound event's file is loaded in RAM. The parameter specified by sound must point to an image of a sound in memory.
No default sound event is used. If the sound cannot be found, PlaySound returns silently without playing the default sound.

description.para: The specified sound event will yield to another sound event that is already playing. If a sound cannot be played because the resource needed to generate that sound is busy playing another sound, the function immediately returns FALSE without playing the requested sound.
If this flag is not specified, PlaySound attempts to stop the currently playing sound so that the device can be used to play the new sound.

item.description: If the driver is busy, return immediately without playing the sound.

description.para: Sounds are to be stopped for the calling task. If sound is not NULL, all instances of the specified sound are stopped. If sound is NULL, all sounds that are playing on behalf of the calling task are stopped.
You must also specify the instance handle to stop events.

item.description: The sound parameter is a resource identifier; mod must identify the instance that contains the resource.
Synchronous playback of a sound event. PlaySound returns after the sound event completes.

member.returns: Returns TRUE if successful or FALSE otherwise.

remarks.para: The sound specified by sound must fit into available physical memory and be playable by an installed waveform-audio device driver. PlaySound searches the following directories for sound files: the current directory; the Windows directory; the Windows system directory; directories listed in the PATH environment variable; and the list of directories mapped in a network. For more information about the directory search order, see the documentation for the OpenFile function.

If it cannot find the specified sound, PlaySound uses the default system event sound entry instead. If the function can find neither the system default entry nor the default sound, it makes no sound and returns FALSE.

member.name: M:Win32.MultiMedia.WinMM.timeBeginPeriod(System.UInt32)
member.summary: The timeBeginPeriod function sets the minimum timer resolution for an application or device driver.
member.param: Minimum timer resolution, in milliseconds, for the application or device driver.
member.returns: Returns if successful or if the resolution specified in period is out of range.

remarks.para: Call this function immediately before using timer services, and call the function immediately after you are finished using the timer services.

You must match each call to timeBeginPeriod with a call to , specifying the same minimum resolution in both calls. An application can make multiple timeBeginPeriod calls as long as each call is matched with a call to .

member.name: M:Win32.MultiMedia.WinMM.timeEndPeriod(System.UInt32)
member.summary: The timeEndPeriod function clears a previously set minimum timer resolution.
member.param: Minimum timer resolution specified in the previous call to the function.
member.returns: Returns if successful or if the resolution specified in period is out of range

remarks.para: Call this function immediately after you are finished using timer services.

You must match each call to with a call to timeEndPeriod, specifying the same minimum resolution in both calls. An application can make multiple calls as long as each call is matched with a call to timeEndPeriod.

member.name: M:Win32.MultiMedia.WinMM.timeGetTime
member.summary: The timeGetTime function retrieves the system time, in milliseconds. The system time is the time elapsed since Windows was started.
member.returns: Returns the system time, in milliseconds.

remarks.para: The only difference between this function and the timeGetSystemTime function is that timeGetSystemTime uses the MMTIME structure to return the system time. The timeGetTime function has less overhead than timeGetSystemTime.

Note that the value returned by the timeGetTime function is a DWORD value. The return value wraps around to 0 every 2^32 milliseconds, which is about 49.71 days. This can cause problems in code that directly uses the timeGetTime return value in computations, particularly where the value is used to control code execution. You should always use the difference between two timeGetTime return values in computations.

Windows NT/2000: The default precision of the timeGetTime function can be five milliseconds or more, depending on the machine. You can use the and functions to increase the precision of timeGetTime. If you do so, the minimum difference between successive values returned by timeGetTime can be as large as the minimum period value set using and . Use the and functions to measure short time intervals at a high resolution.

member.name: M:Win32.MultiMedia.WinMM.joyGetDevCaps(System.UIntPtr,Win32.MultiMedia.WinMM.JOYCAPS@,System.UInt32)
member.summary: The joyGetDevCaps function queries a joystick to determine its capabilities.
member.param: Identifier of the joystick to be queried. Valid values for uJoyID range from -1 to 15. A value of -1 enables retrieval of the szRegKey member of the JOYCAPS structure whether a device is present or not. For Windows NT 4.0, valid values are limited to zero (JOYSTICKID1) and JOYSTICKID2.
Pointer to a structure to contain the capabilities of the joystick.
Size, in bytes, of the JOYCAPS structure.

returns.para: Returns JOYERR_NOERROR if successful or one of the following error values:

- The joystick driver is not present. Windows NT/2000/XP: The specified joystick identifier is invalid. - An invalid parameter was passed. Windows 95/98/Me: The specified joystick identifier is invalid.

remarks.para: Use the function to determine the number of joystick devices supported by the driver.

member.name: M:Win32.MultiMedia.WinMM.joyGetNumDevs
member.summary: The joyGetNumDevs function queries the joystick driver for the number of joysticks it supports.
member.returns: The joyGetNumDevs function returns the number of joysticks supported by the current driver or zero if no driver is installed.

remarks.para: Use the function to determine whether a given joystick is physically attached to the system. If the specified joystick is not connected, joyGetPos returns a error value.

member.name: M:Win32.MultiMedia.WinMM.joyGetPos(System.UInt32,Win32.MultiMedia.WinMM.JOYINFO@)
member.summary: The joyGetPos function queries a joystick for its position and button status.
member.param: Identifier of the joystick to be queried. Valid values for uJoyID range from 0 to 15.
Pointer to a structure that contains the position and button status of the joystick.
member.returns:
Returns if successful or one of the following error values.
- The joystick driver is not present. - An invalid parameter was passed. - The specified joystick is not connected to the system.
member.remarks: For devices that have four to six axes of movement, a point-of-view control, or more than four buttons, use the function.

member.name: M:Win32.MultiMedia.WinMM.joyGetPosEx(System.UInt32,Win32.MultiMedia.WinMM.JOYINFOEX@)
member.summary: The joyGetPosEx function queries a joystick for its position and button status.
member.param: Identifier of the joystick to be queried. Valid values for uJoyID range from 0 to 15.

Pointer to a structure that contains extended position information and button status of the joystick. You must set the dwSize and dwFlags members or joyGetPosEx will fail. The information returned from joyGetPosEx depends on the flags you specify in dwFlags.
member.returns:
Returns JOYERR_NOERROR if successful or one of the following error values.
Returns JOYERR_NOERROR if successful or one of the following error values.
- The joystick driver is not present. - An invalid parameter was passed. - The specified joystick is not connected to the system. - The specified joystick identifier is invalid.
member.remarks: This function provides access to extended devices such as rudder pedals, point-of-view hats, devices with a large number of buttons, and coordinate systems using up to six axes. For joystick devices that use three axes or fewer and have fewer than four buttons, use the joyGetPos function.

member.name: M:Win32.MultiMedia.WinMM.joyGetThreshold(System.UInt32,System.UInt32@)
member.summary: The joyGetThreshold function queries a joystick for its current movement threshold.
member.param: Identifier of the joystick. Valid values for uJoyID range from 0 to 15.
Pointer to a variable that contains the movement threshold value.

returns.para: Returns JOYERR_NOERROR if successful or one of the following error values.
- The joystick driver is not present. - An invalid parameter was passed.

member.remarks: The movement threshold is the distance the joystick must be moved before a joystick position-change message (, , , or ) is sent to a window that has captured the device. The threshold is initially zero.

member.name: M:Win32.MultiMedia.WinMM.joyReleaseCapture(System.UInt32)
member.summary: The joyReleaseCapture function releases the specified captured joystick.
member.param: Identifier of the joystick. Valid values for uJoyID range from 0 to 15.

returns.para: Returns if successful or one of the following error values.

- The joystick driver is not present. - Windows 95/98/Me: The specified joystick device identifier uJoyID is invalid. Windows NT/2000/XP: The specified joystick identifier is valid, but the joystick has not been captured. - Windows NT/2000/XP: The specified joystick device identifier uJoyID is invalid.

member.remarks: Windows 95/98/Me: This method returns JOYERR_NOERROR when passed a valid joystick identifier that has not been captured.

member.name: M:Win32.MultiMedia.WinMM.joySetCapture(System.IntPtr,System.UInt32,System.UInt32,System.Boolean)
member.summary: The joySetCature function captures a joystick by causing its messages to be sent to the specified window.
member.param: Handle to the window to receive the joystick messages.
Identifier of the joystick. Valid values for uJoyID range from 0 to 15.
Polling frequency, in milliseconds.

Change position flag. Specify TRUE for this parameter to send messages only when the position changes by a value greater than the joystick movement threshold. Otherwise, messages are sent at the polling frequency specified in uPeriod.

returns.para: Returns JOYERR_NOERROR if successful or one of the following error values.

- The joystick driver is not present. - Windows 95/98/Me: Invalid joystick ID or hwnd is NULL. - Cannot capture joystick input because a required service (such as a Windows timer) is unavailable. - The specified joystick is not connected to the system. - Windows NT/2000/XP: Invalid joystick ID or hwnd is NULL.

member.remarks: This function fails if the specified joystick is currently captured. Call the joyReleaseCapture function to release the captured joystick, or destroy the window to release the joystick automatically.

member.name: M:Win32.MultiMedia.WinMM.joySetThreshold(System.UInt32,System.UInt32)
member.summary: The joySetThreshold function sets the movement threshold of a joystick.
member.param: Identifier of the joystick. Valid values for uJoyID range from 0 to 15.
New movement threshold.

returns.para: Returns JOYERR_NOERROR if successful or one of the following error values.
- The joystick driver is not present. - The specified joystick device identifier uJoyID is invalid.

member.remarks: The movement threshold is the distance the joystick must be moved before a joystick position-change message (, , , or ) is sent to a window that has captured the device. The threshold is initially zero.

member.name: T:Win32.ACCESS_MASK
member.summary: Defines the access mask.

remarks.para: A uint combining different rights.
Generic access rights are stored in the four uppermost bits (bits 28-31).
The SACL access right is stored in bit 24.
Standard access rights are stored in the bits 16-23.
Specific (access) rights are stored in the lowermost bits 0-15.
The values in this enum are provided for simpler use of the acces mask. Just OR them together to your needs.

member.summary: The buffer supports OpenGL drawing.

member.name: F:Win32.PFD.GENERIC_FORMAT
member.summary: The pixel format is supported by the GDI software implementation, which is also known as the generic implementation. If this bit is clear, the pixel format is supported by a device driver or hardware.

member.name: F:Win32.PFD.NEED_PALETTE
member.summary: The buffer uses RGBA pixels on a palette-managed device.

member.name: F:Win32.PFD.NEED_SYSTEM_PALETTE
member.summary: Defined in the pixel format descriptors of hardware that supports one hardware palette in 256-color mode only.

member.name: F:Win32.PFD.SWAP_EXCHANGE
member.summary: Swapping the color buffers causes the exchange of the back buffer's content with the front buffer's content.

member.name: F:Win32.PFD.SWAP_COPY
member.summary: Swapping the color buffers causes the content of the back buffer to be copied to the front buffer.

member.name: F:Win32.PFD.SWAP_LAYER_BUFFERS
member.summary: Indicates whether a device can swap individual layer planes with pixel formats that include double-buffered overlay or underlay planes. Otherwise all layer planes are swapped together as a group.

member.name: F:Win32.PFD.GENERIC_ACCELERATED
member.summary: The pixel format is supported by a device driver that accelerates the generic implementation (MCD). If this flag is clear and the flag is set, the pixel format is supported by the generic implementation only.

member.name: F:Win32.PFD.SUPPORT_DIRECTDRAW
member.summary: The pixel buffer supports DirectDraw drawing, which allows applications to have low-level control of the output drawing surface.

member.name: F:Win32.PFD.DIRECT3D_ACCELERATED
member.summary: The pixel buffer supports Direct3D drawing, which accellerated rendering in three dimensions.

member.name: F:Win32.PFD.SUPPORT_COMPOSITION
member.summary: The pixel buffer supports compositing, which indicates that source pixels MAY overwrite or be combined with background pixels.

member.name: F:Win32.PFD.DEPTH_DONTCARE
member.summary: The requested pixel format can either have or not have a depth buffer. Only used in .

member.name: F:Win32.PFD.DOUBLEBUFFER_DONTCARE
member.summary: The requested pixel format can be either single- or double-buffered. Only used in .

member.name: F:Win32.PFD.STEREO_DONTCARE
member.summary: The requested pixel format can be either monoscopic or stereoscopic. Only used in .

member.summary: Ignored. Earlier implementations of OpenGL used this member, but it is no longer used.

member.name: T:Win32.CDS
member.summary: Specifies flags for DisplayMode.ChangeDisplaySettings and DisplayMode.ChangeDisplaySettingsEx.

member.name: F:Win32.CDS.NONE
member.summary: The graphics mode for the current screen will be changed dynamically.

member.name: F:Win32.CDS.UPDATEREGISTRY
member.summary: The graphics mode for the current screen will be changed dynamically and the graphics mode will be updated in the registry. The mode information is stored in the USER profile.

member.name: F:Win32.CDS.TEST
member.summary: The system tests if the requested graphics mode could be set.

member.name: F:Win32.CDS.FULLSCREEN
member.summary: The mode is temporary in nature. If you change to and from another desktop, this mode will not be reset.

member.name: F:Win32.CDS.GLOBAL
member.summary: The settings will be saved in the global settings area so that they will affect all users on the machine. Otherwise, only the settings for the user are modified. This flag is only valid when specified with the flag.

member.name: F:Win32.CDS.SET_PRIMARY
member.summary: This device will become the primary device.

member.name: F:Win32.CDS.VIDEOPARAMETERS
member.summary: When set, the lParam parameter of DisplayMode.ChangeDisplaySettingsEx is a pointer to a structure.

member.name: F:Win32.CDS.ENABLE_UNSAFE_MODES
member.summary: Enables settings changes to unsafe graphics modes.

member.name: F:Win32.CDS.DISABLE_UNSAFE_MODES
member.summary: Disables settings changes to unsafe graphics modes.

member.name: F:Win32.CDS.RESET
member.summary: The settings should be changed, even if the requested settings are the same as the current settings.

member.name: F:Win32.CDS.RESET_EX
member.summary: The settings should be changed, even if the requested settings are the same as the current settings.

member.name: F:Win32.CDS.NORESET
member.summary: The settings will be saved in the registry, but will not take effect. This flag is only valid when specified with the flag.

member.summary: For printer devices only, overrides the width of the paper specified by the member.

member.summary: Specifies the factor by which the printed output is to be scaled.

Returns a structure describing the placement of the glyph in the character cell.

If one of these flags is specified and the buffer size or address is zero, the return value specifies the required buffer size, in bytes. If is specified and the function fails, the return value is GDI_ERROR (-1).

member.name: F:Win32.SECURITY_ATTRIBUTES.lpSecurityDescriptor
member.summary: A pointer to a SECURITY_DESCRIPTOR structure that controls access to the object. Default security descriptor is null (IntPtr.Zero).

member.name: F:Win32.SECURITY_ATTRIBUTES.bInheritHandle
member.summary: A bool value that specifies whether the returned handle is inherited when a new process is created. If this member is true, the new process inherits the handle.

member.name: T:Win32.WinKernel
member.summary: Class for miscellaneous kernel32.dll functions.

member.name: M:Win32.WinKernel.GetLastError
member.summary: Retrieves the calling thread's last-error code value. The last-error code is maintained on a per-thread basis. Multiple threads do not overwrite each other's last-error code.
member.remarks: This is for convenience only, you should use in conjunction with set true.
member.returns: The last-error code.

member.name: M:Win32.WinKernel.SetLastError(System.Int32)
member.summary: Sets the last-error code for the calling thread.

member.name: M:Win32.WinKernel.SetLastError(System.UInt32)
member.summary: Sets the last-error code for the calling thread.

member.name: M:Win32.WinKernel.QueryPerformanceCounter(System.Int64@)
member.summary: Retrieves the current value of the performance counter, which is a high resolution (<1s) time stamp that can be used for time-interval measurements.
member.remarks: Use to query the frequency of the counter.
member.param: The variable that receives the current performance-counter value, in counts.
member.returns: true if successful; otherwise, false. Use to get extended error information.

member.name: M:Win32.WinKernel.QueryPerformanceFrequency(System.Int64@)
member.summary: Retrieves the frequency of the performance counter. The frequency of the performance counter is fixed at system boot and is consistent across all processors. Therefore, the frequency need only be queried upon application initialization, and the result can be cached.
member.param: The variable that receives the current performance-counter frequency, in counts per second.
member.returns: true the installed hardware supports a high-resolution performance counter; otherwise, false. Use to get extended error information.
